entry.title: SAP Document AI概况介绍
entry.content:
如果您对BTP感兴趣，BTP个人精选内容目录 | SAP Blogs 可能有更多你需要的内容

 

SAP Document AI是什么？

SAP Document AI是一个文档处理应用，可以提取业务文档（比如发票、采购订单、交货单等）中的数据

 

SAP为什么开发SAP Document AI？

痛点： 企业花费大量人力处理数据，但手动处理十分耗时，成本高昂，还容易出错。

开发目的：通过AI帮助企业减少手动工作量，提高数据提取准确性，加速业务流程处理

 

SAP Document AI的核心能力有哪些？

智能信息提取 - 自动从业务文档中提取相关信息，支持不同版面和布局

预配置业务内容: 提供发票、采购订单、交货单等关键业务文档的预训练模型和提取模板

即时学习 - 通过对提取结果进行标注，即可快速提高提取效果

 

SAP Document AI和市面上常见的类似功能有什么区别？

深度SAP集成: 原生嵌入SAP S/4HANA、Ariba、Concur、SuccessFactors等核心业务应用中，实现无缝集成

企业级AI技术: 采用混合AI（LLM+机器学习）方法，最小化训练数据需求的同时确保准确性

全球化合规支持: 同时在AWS、Azure、GCP等IaaS平台提供，满足本地化合规要求

 

SAP Document AI的常见场景？

发票处理: 自动化个人/对公的发票上传、转换和验证，减少人工录入错误，甚至可以自动触发后续发票验真等流程

对账自动化：自动提取供应商/客户的对账单信息，并与ERP信息做比对，甚至可以直接触发付款申请

销售订单自动化: 自动提取客户的订单信息录入系统，甚至可以直接触发后续的生产，物流订单

 

SAP Document AI如何开发？

核心的数据提取功能开发十分简单，只需要三步

1.定义目标字段

2.上传范例文件（例如发票PDF，照片）

 

3.对识别错误的结果进行点击标注

只需三步，即可开始大批量的提取数据，自动化流程

 

总结

SAP Document AI将AI与业务流程深度集成，为企业提供了一个既智能又可靠的文档处理解决方案，能够显著提升业务效率并降低运营成本。

entry.title: S/4HANA公有云版的内部ABAP拓展
entry.content:
如果您对BTP感兴趣，BTP个人精选内容目录 | SAP Blogs 可能有更多你需要的内容

 

很多人误以为SAP ERP公有云版"阉割"了ABAP开发能力。事实恰恰相反：它不仅保留了ABAP开发的核心能力，还让开发变得更规范、更可靠、更面向未来。

 

SAP如何在ERP公有云版中实现ABAP开发？？

业务现实：

  • 企业需要深度定制来满足特殊业务需求，这是不可避免的。
  • 但传统ABAP扩展方式虽然灵活，却容易导致维护噩梦和升级困难，SAP的内置AI功能更是难以做到开箱即用

在ERP公有云版本中，SAP提供了更智能的开发方式：

  • 关键用户扩展：低代码方式解决大部分的小需求
  • 开发人员扩展：基于ABAP的深度定制，解决复杂需求

重点是：开发人员扩展方式依然是真正的ABAP开发！

 

开发人员拓展方式和传统ABAP代码开发的区别

核心事实：两种方式都是写ABAP代码，区别只是开发规范更严格了

开发活动传统ABAP方式开发人员拓展方式差异说明
开发工具可以采用ADT或内置T-Code必须使用基于Eclipse的ABAP Development Tools（ADT） 
数据模型定义创建数据库表(SE11)创建CDS数据定义和接口视图使用声明式CDS语法，内置元数据注解
业务逻辑实现编写Function Module或Class开发RAP行为定义和行为实现类使用声明式CDS语法，内置元数据注解
服务暴露手动创建RFC/BAPI通过Service Definition自动生成OData服务自动化服务生成，标准OData协议
UI开发开发Dynpro/WebDynpro界面

使用Business Application Studio开发Fiori代码然后部署到S/4HANA中

基于元数据驱动的UI生成

权限控制

手动实现权限检查

通过CDS访问控制和RAP授权

声明式权限模型，集成到框架中

但从拓展可行性角度来看的根本区别是，开发人员拓展方式采用了"白名单"机制：

  • 只能使用SAP官方发布的稳定API和CDS视图
  • 这确保了你的代码在SAP系统升级时不会出问题

所以实际开发前需要确认：

  1. 业务扩展点：确认标准流程提供的BAdI和扩展接口
  2. 数据访问：确认所需业务数据的CDS视图
  3. API可用性：确认所需功能API的发布状态

最后设计目标业务流程，一旦确认完毕，就是标准的ABAP开发流程！

 

实例

接下来以一个完整的ERP公有云开发项目为例，

这个案例将展示完整的'表-逻辑-界面-部署'全栈开发流程，所有代码都运行在S/4HANA系统内部

 

Develop an SAP Fiori App to Trigger Purchase Requisitions API

采购申请应用开发

 

教程概述

这个教程的整体目标是创建一个完整的SAP Fiori应用，用于触发采购申请API。最终成果是一个在线商店应用，客户可以订购商品并在其中创建新的采购申请项目

 

教程步骤：

1.后端开发：

CDS视图数据模型创建

  • 基于CDS视图定义数据模型，为购买申请应用提供数据基础 [3]
  • 创建购物车数据表和相关字段，定义商品信息、数量、价格等关键属性
  • 建立数据关联关系，确保数据完整性和业务逻辑正确性

RAP业务对象开发

  • 创建自定义业务对象以实现业务逻辑
  • 实现购买申请API触发功能，处理商品订购和申请单创建逻辑
  • 配置业务对象行为，包括创建、更新、删除等操作

OData服务生成与激活

  • 通过自动暴露功能生成OData服务，为前端应用提供数据接口
  • 在SAP Gateway系统中激活OData服务，确保服务可被前端调用
  • 配置服务权限和访问控制，保障数据安全

至此，数据表，数据模型，后端逻辑和供前端访问的接口都已经开发好并部署好

2.前端开发：

Fiori应用开发

  • 采用BTP上的SAP Business Application Studio开发Fiori代码
  • 选择List Report Page模板，配置数据源为已创建的OData服务
  • 设置应用基本属性，包括名称、描述和部署配置

前端部署配置

  • 配置Fiori部署目标为ABAP系统的SAP UI5 ABAP Repository
  • 指定包名和传输请求，确保应用正确部署到目标系统
  • 验证Fiori代码是否已经部署到BSP库

至此，前端代码以及和后端的对应关系也已经开发好并部署好

3.权限和访问配置

配置身份权限，配置OData服务访问权限

建立业务目录，将IAM应用分配给相应的业务角色

发布业务目录，使最终用户能够访问应用

 

看完整个开发流程，你应该明白了：

- 后端开发：写的是ABAP代码，部署在S/4HANA系统内

- 前端开发：标准的Fiori开发，同样部署在系统内

- 权限配置：完整的ABAP权限体系

 

所谓的"限制"实际上是"规范"，就像高速公路有护栏不是为了阻止你开车，而是让你开得更快更安全。

 

结论：真相大白

经过完整的技术剖析和实战案例，答案很清楚：SAP ERP公有云版支持体内的ABAP开发，从数据建模到界面开发，从业务逻辑到系统部署，一个都不少。

所谓的"限制"其实是"升级保险"——让你的定制代码在SAP系统演进中始终保持兼容，而不是成为技术债务。

SAP ERP公有云版 = 能开发 + 更安全 + 可持续

entry.title: Authorization management with OpenSearch's Document Level Security - SAP Cloud Logging
entry.content:
The shift to SAP Cloud Logging service introduces several improvements over its predecessor, the SAP Application Logging service (Cloud Foundry). One major benefit is the ability to use a single Cloud Logging instance across multiple CF spaces and even multiple CF orgs/subaccounts. (For more details, see the blog post Instance Sharing – SAP Cloud Logging.)

However, the authorization model is different fromSAP Application Logging service (Cloud Foundry). Application Logging supported only read-only access and implicitly reused CF space permissions.  

Cloud Logging, on the other hand:

  • Supports read/write use cases
  • Allows creating custom content
  • Enables centralization and sharing

In order to support such extended scenarios, Cloud Logging integrates with SAP Cloud Identity Services - Identity Authentication (IAS) for flexible authentication and authorization.

This document guides on how to leverage Document Level Security (DLS) in OpenSearch Roles (+) IAS Groups to setup flexible authorization. It explains using few common use cases including the prominent one - replicating the familiar space-level separation, based on user's CF Space assignment, within a unified logging instance.

  • OpenSearch Security Model Overview
  • Index-Level vs. Document-Level Security
  • The DLS Strategy: Restricting Views by Space ID
  • Use Case 1: Fixed Authorization for Specific Spaces (Space-A and Space-B)
  • Step 1:Create IAS Groups (Backend Roles)
  • Step 2: Define OpenSearch Roles
  • Step 3: Map Backend Roles to OpenSearch Roles
  • Use Case 2: Multi-Space Access for Shared Teams (e.g., Finance)
  • Use Case 3: Using Other Fields
  • Use Case 4: Parameter Substitution for Dynamic Authorization
  • High-Level Overview: IAS Group Mapping and Space-Based Access Control in OpenSearch
  • Important Considerations (DLS Best Practices)
  • 1. Avoid Wildcard Index Match (*) :
  • 2. DLS and Write Permissions:
  • 3. Admin Roles Combined with DLS Roles
  • 4. DLS Query Syntax: Precision is Key

OpenSearch Security Model Overview

OpenSearch's security model provides the foundation for integrating with external Identity Providers (IdPs) like SAP IAS:

ComponentDefinitionIntegration
UsersIndividual accounts accessing OpenSearch.Authenticated via SAP IAS.
OpenSearch Roles

Collections of permissions (read, write, manage) and security filters (DLS).

Cloud Logging ships with default roles, and customers may create additional ones.

The mechanism for authorization.
Backend RolesGroups or roles assigned to the user within the SAML/OIDC Identity Provider — in this case SAP IAS Group names.The bridge between SAP IAS and OpenSearch Roles.
Roles MappingThe link that connects IAS groups (backend roles) to OpenSearch roles. How users inherit OpenSearch permissions.

Note: 

Since IAS groups are customer-defined, Cloud Logging can only pre-map the IAS group that should serve as instance admin to OpenSearch’s all_access role. All other mappings must be configured by the customer.

Index-Level vs. Document-Level Security

  • Index-Level Security controls which indices a user can access.

  • Document-Level Security (DLS) controls which documents inside an index a user can access.

To restrict users to logs from a specific CF space, you apply DLS.

The DLS Strategy: Restricting Views by Space ID

To achieve security separation, every log document must contain a field that identifies its CF source. We assume this field is named space_name (mapped as space_name.keyword in OpenSearch).

DLS works by appending a mandatory filter—an OpenSearch Query DSL statement—to every search request made by a user assigned to the role. This filter ensures the user only retrieves documents where the space_name.keyword matches their authorized space(s).

Use Case 1: Fixed Authorization for Specific Spaces (Space-A and Space-B)

When you have a small number of distinct spaces (e.g., space-A and space-B), and each requires a dedicated authorization group, you create a static OpenSearch Role for each.

Step 1: Create IAS Groups (Backend Roles)

  • space-A-read-only
  • space-B-read-only

Step 2: Define OpenSearch Roles

We will define two roles, each allowing read-only access to log indices but restricted by DLS.

A. Role for Space-A (role-space-A-read-only)

  1. Navigate to OpenSearch Dashboards > Security > Roles.

  2. Clone the default readall role and name it role-space-A-read-only.
  3. Cluster permissions: cluster_composite_ops_ro
  4. Index Permissions:

    • Index Pattern: logs-*(Specify a pattern like this instead of only specifying an asterisk * to avoid applying DLS to system indices).

    • Index Permissions: Select read
    • Document Level Security: Enter the DLS query for the specific space: 
{
  "term": {
    "space_name.keyword": "space-A"
  }
}​

B. Role for Space-B (role-space-B-read-only)

Repeat the above steps for role-space-B-read-only, changing the value in the DLS query to "space-B".

Step 3: Map Backend Roles to OpenSearch Roles

This step links the SAP IAS groups to the newly created security filters.

  1. Navigate to OpenSearch Dashboards > Security > Roles.

  2. Select role-space-A-read-only.

  3. Click the Mapped Users tab and then Manage Mapping.

  4. Under Backend roles, add the SAP IAS group name: space-A-read-only.

Repeat this process for role-space-B-read-only, mapping it to the space-B-read-only backend role.

Crucial Note on Dashboards Access: You must also map these new Backend Roles (space-A-read-only, space-B-read-only)to the OpenSearch role global_tenant_read_access to allow users to see and use shared dashboards and visualizations.

Use Case 2: Multi-Space Access for Shared Teams (e.g., Finance)

If you need to define a single role for a department (e.g., Finance) that needs access to a specific list of CF spaces (space-A, space-C, space-D), you can use terms query to add multiple values.

UI Steps for a finance_spaces_read_only Role:

  1. Clone the default OpenSearch Role readall and name it finance_spaces_read_only.

  2. Set the Index Pattern and Permissions as explained in Use Case 1.
  3. Document Level Security: Enter the terms query to include all required spaces: 
{
  "terms": {
    "space_name.keyword": [
      "space-A",
      "space-C",
      "space-D"
    ]
  }
}

Map this role to the relevant SAP IAS group (e.g., finance_spaces_read_only) as explained in Use Case 1.

Use Case 3: Using Other Fields

The same DLS concepts apply to:

  • organization_id

  • organization_name
  • app_name

You can restrict access on any well-defined keyword field stored in your logs. 

Use Case 4: Parameter Substitution for Dynamic Authorization

For maximum scalability, instead of creating one OpenSearch role per space, you can create a single role that dynamically substitutes the user’s backend roles into the DLS query.

This works when IAS group names match the field values — for example:

  • finance_space_prod
  • finance_space_staging
  • finance_space_dev

In OpenSearch, the variable ${user.roles} references the list of backend roles (IAS groups) assigned to the user.

UI Steps for a Dynamic Role:

  1. Create a single OpenSearch Role (e.g., dynamic_space_member).

  2. Set the Index Pattern and Permissions as before.

  3. Document Level Security: Use the ${user.roles} substitution variable in a terms query: 

{
  "terms": {
    "space_name.keyword": [ ${user.roles} ]
  }
}

Result: When a user logs in, if they are assigned to the IAS groups finance_space_staging and finance_space_dev, the DLS query automatically evaluated to "terms": { "space_name.keyword": ["finance_space_staging", "finance_space_dev"] }. The user is only shown logs where space_name exactly matches one of their assigned IAS groups.

Map this role to a general backend role pattern (e.g., finance_space*) to cover all relevant IAS groups.

 

High-Level Overview: IAS Group Mapping and Space-Based Access Control in OpenSearch

Important Considerations (DLS Best Practices)

1. Avoid Wildcard Index Match (*) :

Avoid using a plain wildcard (*) for index patterns in your DLS roles. This includes system indices (like .kibana), which can break Dashboards functionality when DLS is applied. Always use a targeted pattern like logs-*, otel-*

2. DLS and Write Permissions:

A user with a DLS-configured role must not be granted write permissions. If they index a document they cannot retrieve (due to DLS filtering), it creates invisible data they cannot manage. DLS is intended for read-only access control.

3. Admin Roles Combined with DLS Roles

When a user with multiple roles (usually Admins) logs in, OpenSearch combines DLS rules from multiple roles using a logical OR. However if a restricted role with DLS is combined with a role with empty DLS, the unrestricted role will not override the DLS rule, and access remains restricted according to role with DLS.

This is the secure, expected behaviour:

  • Admin role: empty DLS

  • Restricted role: with a restricted DLS
  • Combined: restricted role takes precedence (since empty DLS does NOT override a restrictive one)

Background: The admin role has an "empty" DLS configuration which by default does not override a restrictive one. In Cloud Logging, plugins.security.dfm_empty_overrides_all is disabled, so empty DLS doesn’t override.

Workaround to Give Admins Full Access

  1. Duplicate the all_access role → all_access_advanced

  2. Change index pattern: from * to a targeted pattern like logs-*
  3. Add a match-all DLS:  {"match_all":{}}
  4. Ensure admin backend role is mapped to this new role.

4. DLS Query Syntax: Precision is Key

For security and performance, use DLS filters with term query on a .keyword field.

# Option 1: works but has limitations

{ 
 "bool": { 
   "must": { 
     "match": { 
       "space_name.keyword": "space-name-A" 
     } 
   } 
 } 
} 

vs. 

# Option 2: preferred
{ 
  "term": { 
    "space_name.keyword": "space-name-A" 
  } 
}
  • Although match  (combined with .keyword) works, it triggers analyzers and scoring logic.
  • Furthermore, it is not guaranteed to remain exact under future mapping or analyzer changes which are risky when used for authorization.
  • term is faster, safer, and the only deterministic option for Lucene-level DLS.
Term Look up: 

If you use term lookup queries (not the simple Term query) or other constructs, DLS falls back to Filter-level DLS instead of the most efficient Lucene-level DLS which might have to be considered when filtering on large data sets. (read more on DLS evaluation modes).

🔚

Official OpenSearch DLS documentation: https://docs.opensearch.org/2.19/security/access-control/document-level-security/

entry.title: 如何在 S/4HANA 公有云版中查找 CDS 视图
entry.content:
本文内容翻译How to find CDS views in S/4HANA Public Cloud Edit... - SAP Community

 

如果您对BTP感兴趣，BTP个人精选内容目录 | SAP Blogs 可能有更多你需要的内容

 

简要概述

通过三层架构的 S/4HANA 公有云版，您现在可以将 ABAP 开发工具（ADT，在 Eclipse 中）直接连接到系统。您可以浏览开发对象，包括 CDS 视图。创建 ABAP 存储库树可让您按组件和发布状态浏览，以查找已发布的视图用于您的扩展。

 

提醒一下，什么是 S/4HANA 公有云版？

S/4HANA 公有云版（或公有 CE）是 SAP 的 SaaS ERP。它之前被称为 S/4HANA Cloud 和 S/4HANA Public Cloud，这种 S/4 变体强调与标准业务流程的紧密契合。该解决方案由 SAP 托管和管理。只能进行清洁核心扩展，升级按照发布的时间表进行。

 

为什么 S/4HANA 公有云版很重要？

虽然最大的客户往往在 SAP 世界中最受关注，但他们的数量是有限的。当您将目光放宽到包括越来越小的客户时，他们的数量会更加显著。

换句话说，拥有 10,000 名员工的公司比拥有 100,000 名员工的公司多得多。拥有 1,000 名员工的公司比拥有 10,000 名员工的公司多得多。

这意味着总市场是巨大的，即使每个单独的订阅较小。

 

在其他条件相同的情况下，这些较小的客户更可能选择S/4HANA公有云，因为对他们来说可能更具成本效益。

实际上，无法执行"脏"扩展和增强，以及无法停留在过时版本上，可以被视为S/4HANA公有云的优势。

SAP 的愿景是随着时间的推移，越来越多的客户将转向S/4HANA公有云，其中一些在"清理"其遗留增强后转换。

 

我们如何扩展 S/4HANA 公有云版？

虽然适应标准流程是目标，但S/4HANA公有云可以在需要时进行扩展和增强。这些扩展方式可以分类为：

 

堆栈上的关键用户扩展

BTP 上的并行开发者构建扩展

 

为了支持后一种类型，我们通过 SAP 发布的标准 API、创建自定义 CDS 视图或创建启用后端服务的自定义业务对象来公开数据。事件也可以触发 BTP 上的扩展。

 

为什么已发布的视图很宝贵？

要公开不属于已发布 API 的标准数据，我们必须（如果是双层架构）使用自定义 CDS 视图选项。我们只能使用已发布的视图作为源，而只有一小部分视图是已发布的。

为什么呢？因为发布视图对 SAP 来说是一件大事，它代表着保持该视图可用和最新的承诺。如果不是这样的话，我们的扩展可能在每个升级周期都会中断，因为标准视图的修改。这将完全限制S/4HANA公有云的可行性。

 

因此，找到具有正确数据的已发布视图是扩展设计的重要部分。令人高兴的是，随着公有 CE 三层架构的普及，这项任务变得越来越容易。

 

为什么三层架构比双层架构更好？

当我的第一个客户在 2019 年使用S/4HANA公有云上线时，所有设置都只有测试和生产环境。有些大型本地客户背景，他们有 5 或 6 层架构（例如沙箱/开发/测试/预生产/生产/培训），我发现这非常可怕！

 

现在所有新的S/4HANA公有云客户都获得三层架构（开发/测试/生产），现有客户正在迁移。

开发环境有两个租户，用于开发和定制。在底层，这些分别代表客户端 80 和客户端 100。这促进了新增强技术的引入。使用嵌入式 ABAP Cloud 环境，我们可以使用 RAP（ABAP RESTful 编程模型）构建 OData 服务。这比我们在 Fiori 应用程序中构建自定义 CDS 视图（作为"关键用户"）获得的灵活性要大得多。

 

这种堆栈上扩展性一度被称为嵌入式 Steampunk。

 

当然，找到已发布的 CDS 视图仍然很重要，因为 ABAP Cloud 只允许我们使用已发布的 CDS 视图作为数据源。那么找到它们的最佳方法是什么？

 

在S/4HANA公有云中查找已发布 CDS 视图的最佳方法是什么？

一旦您将ADT（ ABAP 开发工具）连接到 S/4HANA 公有云版系统（开发租户/客户端 80），您就可以浏览所有开发对象。这在以前是不可能的，因为我们只能看到各种 Fiori 应用程序中的内容。

 

如果您尝试浏览所有 CDS 视图，您可能会遇到问题，因为有太多无法渲染。我建议改为构建您自己的 ABAP 存储库树（通过文件->新建）。

 

在第一个屏幕（存储库树向导）上，选择 Core Data Services。

 

 

在下一个屏幕中，在Selected Tree Levels中，从级别 3 中移除包，并用Application Component替换它。然后选择将 API State 级别拖动到级别 4。

 

 

单击完成。现在，在树中，您可以打开 Core Data Services、Data Definitions，然后选择您选择的组件。已发布的视图可在 USE_IN_CLOUD_DEVELOPMENT 下找到。您可以打开单个视图查看定义。

 

 

您可以通过查看 Eclipse 屏幕右下角属性中的 API 状态选项卡来确认视图已发布。C1 Use System Internally 是关键部分。如果它是已发布的，您应该能够在自定义 CDS 视图或 RAP 开发中使用此视图。

 

 

因为您已经连接到了开发系统，所以可以看到当前版本上可用的每个CDS View的发布状态。

 

您怎么看？

您已经是扩展专家了吗？还是对 S/4HANA 公有云版有如此多的扩展范围感到惊讶？扩展确实变得容易了一些，现在我们可以看到所有可用的视图。请在评论中告诉我您的想法，以及是否有查找视图的技巧。

 

我很想找到一个好方法来查找使用给定表作为源（直接或间接）的 CDS 视图。这可以在View Browser App中完成，但我们不会看到所有视图。也许将来 SAP 可以在 ADT 中支持"在哪里使用过"功能。

entry.title: Expose SAP CPI Integration Flows as APIs Using SAP API Management: A Step-by-Step Guide
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Integration Suite empowers businesses to integrate applications and processes efficiently. One powerful capability is exposing CPI integration flows as APIs via API Management (APIM). This enables centralized governance, security, and monitoring of APIs. In this blog, we’ll cover the step-by-step process to achieve this.

Step 1: Set Up SAP Process Integration Runtime

Navigate to SAP BTP Cockpit → Subaccount → Instances & Subscriptions.

  • Create Service Instance
    • Service: SAP Process Integration Runtime
    • Plan: api
    • Instance Name: e.g. CPI_API_Instance
    • Assign all roles (except security roles)Create Service Key

      Click the ⋮ (three-dot menu) → Create Service Key → Save credentials (Client ID, Client Secret, Token URL).

Step 2: Design & Deploy a Sample iFlow

In Integration Suite:

  • Create Package:
    Navigate to Design → Integrations & APIs → Create Package (e.g. Demo_API_Package).

  • Build iFlow:
    Add an HTTP Sender and a Content Modifier (set sample body content).
    Deploy the iFlow.

 

 

 

Step 3: Configure API Provider with OAuth2

In API Management:

  • Create API Provider:
    Navigate to Configure → API Providers → Create New.
    • Name: CPI_Provider
    • Connection Type: Cloud Integration
    • Host: Use host from Service Key
    • Authentication: OAuth2 Client Credentials
      • Enter Client ID, Client Secret, Token URL

 

Step 4: Create & Deploy API Proxy

  • Create API Proxy:
    Select the API Provider → Click Discover → Choose deployed iFlow.
    Enable OAuth and provide credentials.
    • Proxy Name: flow-api-proxy
    • Save & Deploy.

 

Step 5: Test Your API

Use Postman:

  • Paste the Proxy URL
  • Send a request
  • Confirm the response from your iFlow.

 

Conclusion

By exposing SAP CPI integration flows as managed APIs through SAP API Management, you create a robust integration layer that blends flexibility with strong governance. This approach offers several key benefits:

  • Centralized Control: Manage all APIs from a single platform, making lifecycle management simple and efficient.
  • Enhanced Security: Protect your integrations with OAuth2 and other security policies to prevent unauthorized access.
  • Scalability & Reusability: Reuse APIs across multiple applications and business processes, cutting down development time and effort.
  • Comprehensive Monitoring: Gain full visibility into API performance and usage with built-in analytics and dashboards.

This setup not only streamlines integration but also supports modern API-driven architectures, enabling faster innovation and better interoperability across your enterprise. As a next step, consider adding features like rate limiting, caching, and custom policies in API Management to further boost performance and security.

如果您对BTP感兴趣，BTP个人精选内容目录 | SAP Blogs 可能有更多你需要的内容

本博客提供了查找SAP APIs相关资源的概览，所有资源的内容都是相同的。

entry.title: 如何查询S/4HANA公有云内可用的API和数据模型
entry.content:
本文内容主要来自How to find SAP APIs for SAP S/4HANA extensibility... - SAP Community 和 How to find CDS views in S/4HANA Public Cloud Edit... - SAP Community

 

概述

在SAP S/4HANA Cloud系统中基于Clean Core模式开发扩展代码时，需要调用SAP API和CDS View以访问SAP标准对象和数据。本文提供查找SAP APIs和数据模型的完整指南。

1.查询数据模型（CDS View）的方法

1.1通过三层架构的S/4HANA公有云版，可将ABAP Development Tools（ADT）直接连接到系统，浏览各种可用的开发对象。

操作步骤

  • 将本地电脑安装的ADT连接到S/4HANA公有云版系统（开发租户/客户端80）

  • 创建ABAP存储库树：

    • 通过文件->新建创建存储库树
    • 第一个屏幕选择"Core Data Services"
    •  
    • 下一个屏幕的Selected Tree Levels中：
      • 从级别3移除包
      • 用Application Component替换
      • 将API State级别拖动到级别4

    •  

  • 查找已发布视图：

    • 打开Core Data Services -> Data Definitions
    • 选择相应组件
    • 已发布视图位于USE_IN_CLOUD_DEVELOPMENT下

    •  

  • 确认视图发布状态：

    • 查看Eclipse右下角属性中的API状态选项卡
    • "C1 Use System Internally"是关键标识
    • 已发布视图可由ABAP代码或者其他自定义CDS视图使用

 

1.2. 在SAP Business Acceleration Hub上

SAP Business Acceleration Hub提供相关产品的CDS：

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Cloud Edition

 

2.查询可用API的方法

2.1. 在Eclipse的ABAP开发工具中

在ABAP development tools for Eclipse中创建ABAP存储库树：

  • 在Project Explorer的项目节点上右键选择New->ABAP Repository Tree
  • 从Create Tree wizard列表中选择"Released Objects"
  • 点击Next，输入名称"Released Objects"，点击Finish

  •  

注意API适用范围：

  • USE_IN_CLOUD_DEVELOPMENT：适用于S/4HANA Cloud公有云
  • USE_IN_CLOUD_DEVLPMNT_ACTIVE：适用于S/4HANA私有云

2.2. 在SAP Business Acceleration Hub上

SAP Business Acceleration Hub提供相关SAP S/4HANA产品的SAP APIs：

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Cloud Edition
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Cloud Edition

在Developer Extensibility下可找到ABAP Cloud已发布APIs的详细信息，包括行为定义（Behavior Definitions）、CDS视图、Cloud BAdIs等主要对象类型。

2.3. 在GitHub上

SAP在GitHub的Cloudification Repository提供相关SAP APIs列表（.json和.csv格式）：

  • 地址：SAP/abap-atc-cr-cv-s4hc (github.com)
  • 提供纯技术列表，可在ATC检查"Cloud Readiness"中复用
  • 包含已发布对象、其他技术对象（类、授权等）
  • 可查看已弃用对象、经典APIs、非发布APIs及后继者信息

2.4. 在Cloudification Repository Viewer中

使用Cloudification Repository Viewer便捷访问SAP APIs列表：

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2023 FPS2
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition - Classic APIs

功能特点：

  • 点击可查看详细信息和可用后继者
  • 使用Show Filter Bar选择适合产品的相关APIs列表
  • 支持ATC检查"Usage of APIs"和"Allowed Enhancement Technologies"

2.5. 外部工具

还有外部工具（如Software-Heroes）使用上述信息提供服务。

 

总结

查询S/4HANA公有云可用API和数据模型的主要方法包括：

  1. Eclipse ADT中的存储库树
  2. SAP Business Acceleration Hub
  3. GitHub Cloudification Repository
  4. Cloudification Repository Viewer
  5. 外部工具

对于数据模型查询，通过ADT直接连接系统并创建按组件和发布状态分类的存储库树是最有效的方法。这些工具和方法为clean core扩展开发提供了完整的资源支持。

entry.title: How to build an AI side by side extension for Fieldglass
entry.content:
In this blog post, we’ll walk you through building a side-by-side extension that combines SAP BTP’s AI capabilities with Fieldglass to streamline external worker onboarding. Using a practical example, we demonstrate how to create an intelligent document validation system that automatically reviews content of worker documents (ID, criminal records, debt collection statements, and confidentiality agreements) against company guidelines. The AI-powered extension extracts key content from documents, validates it using large language models, and presents summarized findings to end users for final approval or rejection decisions. This approach with GenAI Hub to protect these sensitive information significantly reduces manual review time while ensuring compliance, with all decisions automatically documented back in Fieldglass for complete audit trails.

In this example we test with for types of documents:

  • ID
  • Debt collection
  • Criminal record
  • Confidential agreement

Architecture:

Document AI: Service to retrieve the information from the different types of documents. For each document there is a specific schema defined

HANA Cloud: Stores all the needed data for the workflow/UI. Possibility to compare document to reference document. Also stores the guidelines that are used to check the entries from the documents

SAP AI Core: Access to the different LLMs. Used to decide if the entries found with Document AI are acceptable per guideline or not. Summarizes the findings for the end user and gives recommendation

Destination Service: Stores the credentials for OAuth2 and other relevant API data to access SAP Fieldglass from the CAP application. You need to generate an API key for Fieldglass (sap help documentation)

Process Flow:

Here is a very basic overview of the process flow of the application:

 

We retrieve all workorders from Fieldglass and for all new ones we also retrieve the documents. If all documents are available for a work order we start the validation process. Validated will be ID (Name, birthday), confidential agreement (signed not signed), debt collection and credit statement are checked for entries. Results are validated over AI Core based on company guidelines. Resulting summary of findings are being displayed in the Fiori App to decide. The decision is then being sent over API to Fieldglass with a approval comment or a reject reason. The decision is being documented in Fieldglass. For each document type there is an Activity Item which has the verification setting enabled so we can accept, reject it

User interface:

The user can see the summary of the users entries, the current item being validated and the items that already have been validated. The user can also look up the original document to cross check the summary if needed.
 

APIs and endpoints:

Fieldglass APIs:

The Fieldglass APIs are, to be honest, not that straight forward 😉

For this example we used the following APIs:

  • Activity Item Completion Upload (help, API docu)
    • To set the status of the Fieldglass Activity Items as Rejected, Completed or Verify and with the reject reason/comment
  • Work Order Delta Download (help, API docu)
    • For retrieving all the work orders. Be aware this gets you a delta since the last call! Not all Work orders
  • Worker from Work Order Download (help, API doc)
    • Fetch all information of the worker (name, security level etc.)
  • Attachment XML Download (help, <no API available in business accelerator hub)
    • For retrieving all relevant documents from a specific work order
    • Parameters need to be set like the following
      • ?object_ref=Activity Item~${workOrderID}~${activityItem}
      • The "activityItem" variable is a code you need to look up in the admin configuration  and specifies what Activity Item you want to retrieve: Go to Admin Configuration -> Activity Item -> then search for you Activity Item and get the according code

Be aware of the Fieldglass APIs ;D

  • A lot of the FG APIs accept only csv in the request body. Make sure you sent the correct value in the correct cell. Use for example Excel if you want to make sure that you entered the correct values underneath the correct header as csv can be hard to read in just plain text and you can easily enter your value in the wrong column
  • They can have spaces in the request URL. Make sure they are correctly encoded by the REST client used
  • Some APIs do not make a full read but only a delta of the underlying entities
    • You can reset the last fetch in Fieldglass if needed for testing
  • In General be very aware of the API syntax as it can be unusual when comparing to the structure of other APIs. For example the syntax of the parameters for the Attachment XML Download  with the "~"  in between. E.g. for the download the parameter differs greatly depending if you want attachments from an Activity Item or a SOW

In conclusion read the documentation very carefully on the business accelerator hub AND the help portal

How to call the Document AI Service:

To get the URL of the we bind the Document AI Service to our application and used the function "getServiceBinding" to  retrieve all the required properties (@sap-cloud-sdk/connectivity package)

For starting a job in Document AI you need to set the following headers and make a POST Request:

Header field

Value

Desciption

clientId

<clientId>

You can call this Api to retrieve all client ids

documentType

<documentType>

The type of document being uploaded. Choices: 'invoice', 'paymentAdvice', 'purchaseOrder', 'businessCard', 'deliveryNote', 'resume', 'birthCertificate'
'custom' if you created one yourself

schemaId

<schemaId>

The schema you want to use for your document. (get all schemas with this api)

schemaVersion

<schemaVersion>

The version of your schema

 

Content-Type

Multipart/form-data

 

 

As a response you should receive the jobId this jobId is needed to call the service again later for the result.

In our case we configured the callback from the service, so it calls our application when the job is finished and all results have been extracted. Check this out, to see how this is done. Make sure you have created a configuration key and set "activateDocumentNotifications" to true otherwise the service will not perform a callback. Configure the destination for the callback accordingly.

When the service performs the callback with the job id you can use this to make a GET request to fetch the results of the job. This information is then used to further process the documents and later sent to AI Core.

You can use predefined schemas or you can define your own schemasd. In our case we defined custom schemas. Check out the help portal for schemas

How to call the AI Core

For using the AI Core you can use the provided SDK which fits you best. In our case as we are working with CAP and a NodeJS backend we used the SAP Cloud SDK for AI (JavaScript). We then utilized the Orchestration Service which enables us to quickly change back and forth between the difference models if needed

Set up for side by side extension with Fieldglass:

All APIs of Fieldglass are available in the business accelerator hub and in the help portal

For making HTTP requests to FG you need to have an API Key. Here is a short Joule for consultant explanation on how to do that or check out this help documentation:

Step-by-Step Instructions for API Key Generation:

  1. Access Configuration Manager Dashboard
    1. Sign into SAP Fieldglass using your standard credentials$
    2. Switch to Configuration Manager user: Click your user icon in the upper right corner and select "Linked Accounts"
    3. Navigate to the Configuration Manager dashboard - this provides access to integration tools and administrative functions
  2. Create the API Application Key
    1. Click the "API Application Keys" tile on the Configuration Manager dashboard
    2. Click "New" to create a new API key
    3. Fill out the form with the following required information:
      1. Application Name: Enter a unique, descriptive name (e.g., "SAP Start Integration")
      2. Description: Provide a clear description of the API key's purpose (e.g., "API Key for SAP Start Integration")
    4. Click "Create" to generate the API key
    5. Capture Generated Credentials

After creation, the system will display auto-generated values:

  • Application Key (auto-generated)
  • Client ID (auto-generated)
  • Client Secret (auto-generated)

!!! Important: Copy these values to a secure location immediately, as you cannot retrieve them later !!!

BTP Destination:

Create a BTP destination with the url, credentials and Oauth Url from the API key. Choose "OAuth2ClientCredentials" as Authentication. Don't know how to create a destination? Check this out!

You can now call the SAP Fieldglass APIs over this destination. In case of errors try to call SAP Fieldglass with an REST Client like Postman or Bruno

You can retrieve the destination in CAP for example with the @sap-cloud-sdk/connectivity package with the getDestination function and then make an axios call to Fieldglass

Conclusion:

Congratulations! Using the example of an AI-powered external worker document validation system, you’ve learned how to build a side-by-side extension for Fieldglass with SAP BTP’s AI services. Through this practical use case, you now understand how to leverage SAP Document AI for intelligent document processing, SAP AI Core with its LLMs for automated guideline validation, and navigate the unique challenges of Fieldglass APIs - from CSV request bodies to URL encoding quirks. With this real-world example as your foundation, you’re ready to create your own intelligent automation solutions that enhance Fieldglass 🚀

Special thanks also goes to Matthias Beeler for the technical implementation and realization and Sven Breuninger and Kevin Hornung for the Fieldglass expertise that made this PoC possible.

entry.title: Introduction to FinOps for Project and Program Managers
entry.content:
Introduction to FinOps for Project and Program Managers

(Understanding cost accountability in SAP cloud programmes)

Why FinOps Matters to Project and Program Managers

If you manage SAP projects or large transformation programmes, you will already recognise how significantly the cloud has altered the delivery landscape. Environments can now be provisioned quickly, capacity can be scaled with relative ease, and new services can be activated faster than in traditional on-premise models. This flexibility has undoubtedly improved speed and responsiveness, but it has also introduced a new dimension of financial complexity.

 

What is often less visible in the early stages of cloud adoption is how these technical choices translate into variable and sometimes unpredictable cost patterns. Consumption is no longer tied to fixed infrastructure sizing. Instead, spending fluctuates with usage, behaviour, and architectural choices. The financial impact is fully understood when bills are reviewed or budget thresholds are approached.

In one of the accounts I supported, the customer delivery and business teams initially struggled to grasp what FinOps really meant in practical terms. The focus remained firmly on technical readiness and go-live milestones, while cloud cost accountability was seen as something to address later. It only became a concern when increased consumption began affecting budget forecasts and triggering internal escalations. That experience reinforced for me that FinOps cannot be introduced as an afterthought — it needs to be positioned early as part of programme governance, not merely as a financial control mechanism.

This is where FinOps becomes relevant to project and programme leadership.

 

What FinOps Is – In Practical Terms

FinOps is the discipline of integrating financial awareness and accountability into cloud consumption decisions. In practical terms, it encourages collaboration among technology teams, finance functions, and business stakeholders to align cost considerations with performance, scope, and delivery timelines.

For project and programme managers, this does not mean becoming financial analysts or taking over cost control responsibilities. Instead, it involves understanding how delivery decisions influence cloud spending and ensuring that governance forums provide visibility into those implications.

 

FinOps helps project leaders ask practical questions such as:

  • Do we understand how our cloud environments are consuming resources?
  • Are the cost implications of design choices clearly communicated?
  • Is there clarity on who monitors and responds to cost trends?

 

Seen this way, FinOps becomes less about accounting and more about informed governance.

 

Where Project and Program Managers Fit In

It is essential to be clear that FinOps is not formally defined within SAP delivery methodologies as a direct responsibility of the Project or Program Manager. In most organisations, ownership typically resides with Cloud Centres of Excellence, platform governance functions, or financial oversight teams.

However, project and programme leaders occupy a unique position of influence. They shape delivery decisions, chair governance meetings, manage risks, and oversee the transition into steady-state operations. This puts them in a strong position to ensure cost accountability is not overlooked during execution.

In practice, this influence may take the form of:

  • Encouraging visibility of cloud usage and cost trends in governance forums
  • Ensuring cost implications are considered during scope or design changes
  • Supporting clarity on ownership for cost monitoring post go-live

These actions do not replace formal FinOps ownership; they strengthen alignment during the delivery lifecycle.

A Simple View of the FinOps Lifecycle

FinOps is commonly described through three broad stages:

  • Inform – Gaining visibility into consumption and spend
  • Optimise – Using that visibility to improve efficiency and decision-making
  • Operate – Embedding monitoring and governance into ongoing operations

 

 

From a project and programme management perspective, this broadly translates into:

  • Ensuring cost visibility mechanisms exist during delivery
  • Making sure cost is part of decision-making discussions
  • Supporting the continuity of monitoring after go-live

The above aspects are not SAP-mandated interpretations, but a practical lens that helps clarify where FinOps intersects with delivery governance.

SAP BTP and Cost Visibility

Within SAP landscapes, SAP Business Technology Platform provides standard capabilities that support cost transparency and monitoring, including:

  • Cost and usage views at the global account level
  • Usage analytics at the subaccount level
  • Budget thresholds and alert mechanisms
  • Exportable usage data for reporting and analysis

Platform administrators or governance teams typically manage these tools. While project and programme managers are not expected to configure these capabilities, awareness of their existence helps them engage more effectively in governance discussions and ask the right questions around visibility and accountability.

 

Typical Risks When FinOps Is Overlooked

When cost accountability is not actively considered during delivery, programmes may encounter:

  • Unexpected cost escalation
  • Friction between IT and Finance over cost attribution
  • Delayed identification of inefficient consumption patterns
  • Reduced transparency during steering committee discussions

Recognising these risks early allows project leaders to introduce corrective governance measures before issues become financially disruptive.

 

What This Means for Project and Program Managers

For those leading SAP cloud initiatives, FinOps represents more of a mindset shift than a new operational burden. It encourages leaders to:

  • Integrate cost awareness into regular governance conversations
  • Avoid treating cloud spend as a secondary concern
  • Support structured handovers into steady-state operations

Even modest improvements in visibility and dialogue can lead to more informed decisions and better financial outcomes over time.

 

In Closing

FinOps introduces a structured approach to cost awareness that complements traditional project and programme management controls. While formal ownership of FinOps usually sits outside the PM function, project and programme leaders play an essential role in shaping how cost transparency is embedded during delivery.

Understanding the fundamentals of FinOps, knowing where it intersects with governance, and recognising when to engage the right stakeholders can significantly strengthen the financial resilience of SAP cloud programmes. For many delivery leaders, FinOps is less about controlling cost and more about making cost visible, understandable, and actionable at the right points in the project lifecycle.

 

References

SAP Help Portal – SAP Business Technology Platform: Costs & Usage
Documentation covering monitoring, analysis, and governance of usage and cost within SAP BTP environments.

SAP Help Portal – SAP Cloud Governance and Account Administration
Guidance on account structures, entitlement management, and governance responsibilities supporting cost visibility and financial control.

entry.title: How AI Solutions Can Align with SAP’s Clean Core Principles
entry.content:
“Clean core” and “Artificial Intelligence” are often discussed in isolation. Clean core is positioned to reduce technical debt and keep SAP S/4HANA upgradeable, while AI is usually associated with new workloads, additional components, and non-SAP technologies such as Python.

This separation leads to a common misconception: that AI solutions, especially those implemented in Python or using external models, are incompatible with a clean core strategy.

In practice, AI and clean core are closely aligned. SAP’s own definition of an ERP clean core emphasizes standardization, modern extensibility, and the ability to leverage reliable data and AI innovations on top of a stable core. When designed correctly, AI solutions can fully comply with clean core principles and in many cases help to realize the intended benefits of the strategy.

SAP Clean Core Strategy

SAP describes an ERP clean core strategy as a set of guiding principles to keep business critical systems agile, cost-effective, and ready to adopt innovation. Key elements include:

  • Reduction of historically grown complexity and custom code in the core ERP system.
  • Standardization of processes by staying close to SAP best practices.
  • Use of modern extensibility options, particularly side-by-side extensions on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).
  • API- first and event-driven integration, rather than direct database access.
  • Cloud readiness and continuous innovation, including the ability to exploit AI capabilities.

Clean core does not prohibit custom logic or non-ABAP technology. It defines where that logic should run (outside the S/4 core) and how it should integrate (through released, supported interfaces).

Principles Relevant for AI Solutions

For AI initiatives, the following clean core principles are particularly relevant:

  • Decoupled innovation: AI workloads should run outside the S/4HANA core, typically on SAP BTP, and consume data via published APIs or data services.
  • Use of official extensibility models: Extensions should follow the models described in SAP’s clean core and extensibility guidance, including in-app extensions, developer extensibility (ABAP Cloud), and side-by-side extensions.
  • API-first and event-driven patterns: AI components should use official APIs and events to interact with core applications, rather than relying on direct table access or modifications.
  • Governed data access: Data for AI models should be accessed through governed layers such as SAP HANA Cloud or SAP Datasphere, which preserve security, compliance and lineage.

If an AI architecture respects these principles, it is aligned with the clean core strategy, regardless of the programming language or specific AI framework used.

Clean-Core Compliant AI Architecture Patterns

Side-by-Side AI on SAP BTP

SAP’s “Generative AI on SAP BTP” reference architecture explicitly positions SAP BTP as the platform for AI workloads, with S/4HANA and other SAP cloud solutions used as systems of record.

In a side-by-side pattern:

  • SAP S/4HANA
    • Hosts standard business processes and transactional data.
    • Exposes business functionality via released OData/REST APIs and events.
  • SAP BTP (AI and application layer)
    • Runs AI workloads using SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad, where models and pipelines can be implemented in Python or other languages.
    • Uses SAP Generative AI Hub for LLM access, prompt orchestration, retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), and agentic scenarios.
  • Integration
    • Uses SAP Integration Suite, API Management and/or Event Mesh to connect AI components with S/4HANA through supported interfaces.

 

                       

AI workloads remain in the BTP extension layer, while SAP S/4HANA stays as the clean, standard core accessed via published APIs.

This pattern adheres to clean core because all custom AI logic and orchestration stay outside the S/4HANA core, while S/4HANA is accessed only via documented integration points.

AI Enabled Data Layer with SAP HANA Cloud

SAP has started using the term “AI enabled clean core with SAP HANA Cloud”, referring to architectures where S/4HANA remains the core ERP and SAP HANA Cloud provides an intelligent data layer for analytics and AI-driven applications.

Key characteristics:

  • Operational data is exposed or replicated from S/4HANA to SAP HANA Cloud or SAP Datasphere in a governed way.
  • AI models (classical ML or generative) are trained and executed against this data layer.
  • AI outputs are surfaced in side-by-side applications or written back into S/4HANA via APIs and standard extension points.

The core ERP remains clean and standard. AI driven logic is implemented in the surrounding data and application layers, which aligns with SAP’s stated goal of “increasing the pace of innovation and leveraging business value through reliable data and AI innovations” without compromising the core.

Programming Language and Clean Core Compliance

A frequent objection is that AI solutions are implemented in Python or with non-SAP frameworks and therefore cannot be reconciled with clean core.

From SAP’s standpoint, this is not correct. The clean core strategy focuses on minimizing custom code inside the core and using side-by-side extensions on SAP BTP to build new applications and innovations.

SAP’s own extensibility guidance explicitly acknowledges BTP side-by-side extensions implemented in ABAP Cloud, Java, Node.js and other languages. AI services developed in Python and deployed on SAP AI Core or container runtimes on BTP fall into exactly the same category.

Clean core compliance therefore depends on:

  • The location of the code (outside S/4HANA vs. in-core modifications).
  • The integration pattern (released APIs and events vs. direct table access).

It does not depend on whether the AI logic is written in ABAP, Python, Java or another language.

 

                                    

AI solutions built on SAP BTP and SAP HANA Cloud surrounding a clean SAP S/4HANA core, with integration strictly via APIs and events.

 

SAP’s clean core strategy is often misunderstood as a constraint on innovation. It provides the architectural discipline required to adopt AI at scale without compromising the stability and upgradeability of SAP S/4HANA.

By:

  • keeping AI workloads on SAP BTP and SAP HANA Cloud,
  • integrating through released APIs and events, and
  • applying SAP’s extensibility guidance consistently,

organizations can build advanced AI solutions that are fully aligned with clean core principles. The question is not whether AI is compatible with clean core, but whether AI architectures are designed to follow the same patterns that SAP itself recommends for any modern extension.

entry.title: A Practical Real-Time CTI Widget for SAP Sales Cloud V2
entry.content:
Over the last weeks, I've been working on a CTI widget for SAP Sales Cloud V2 and wanted to share the practical setup I used to get it running in a production-ready way. The goal was simple: receive real-time call events from a telephony system and push them into Sales Cloud without relying on any custom back-end inside the CRM.

A small CAP backend, a WebSocket channel, and a UI5 widget were enough to make this work end-to-end.

Overall Architecture

The widget runs in an iframe inside SAP Sales Cloud. A CAP service on BTP receives call events from the telephony provider and forwards them to the widget via WebSocket. The widget then sends a formatted XML payload back to Sales Cloud using postMessage.

 

CAP Service with WebSocket Support

The backend uses CAP v9 with Websocket enabled so the widget can react immediately to incoming call events.

@protocol: ['websocket', 'odata']
service WidgetService {
  action notifyEvent(
      date : String,
      caller : String,
      isAnonymous : String,
      callee : String,
      event : String,
      direction : String,
      LID : String
  ) returns String;

  event eventNotification : CTIEvent;
}

Event Handler is handling the incoming event and emits it to connected WebSocket clients. 

this.on("notifyEvent", async (req) => {
  const eventData = req.data;
  await this.emit('eventNotification', eventData);
  return 'OK';
});

WebSocket channel is enabled using the @cap-js-community/websocket plugin. Also we configured the xs-app.json file.

{
"websockets": {
    "enabled": true
  }
}

Mapping the CTI Event for Sales Cloud

Sales Cloud expects a specific XML payload.
The widget maps incoming CTI data into that format.

function mapToSapPayload(cti) {
  const ev = (cti.event ?? "").toUpperCase();
  const dir = (cti.direction ?? "").toUpperCase();

  let eventType = dir === "OUTBOUND" ? "OUTBOUND" : "INBOUND";
  let action = "NOTIFY";

  switch (ev) {
    case "CONNECTED":
    case "ANSWERED":
      action = "ACCEPT";
      break;
    case "ENDED":
      action = "END";
      eventType = "UPDATEACTIVITY";
      break;
  }

  return {
    Type: "CALL",
    EventType: eventType,
    Action: action,
    ANI: cti.caller || "",
    ExternalReferenceID: cti.LID
  };
}

Sending the Event to Sales Cloud (postMessage)

The widget sends the XML using a postMessage call. After that, SAP Sales Cloud receives it and Desktop Agent creating a new live Interaction. See more in @lloyd_goveia 's post called 'How Can You Simplify SAP Service Cloud CTI Integration Testing? Try This Dynamic POC Widget!'.

const xml = jsonToXml(sapPayload);
window.parent.postMessage(xml, "*");

Here is an example payload. See more in SAP Help Portal.

<payload>
  <Type>CALL</Type>
  <EventType>INBOUND</EventType>
  <Action>NOTIFY</Action>
  <ANI>+123456789</ANI>
  <ExternalReferenceID>CALL123</ExternalReferenceID>
</payload>

SAP Sales Cloud reads sent mesagge only if CTI is enabled for the tenant, follow the SAP Help Portal doc for more detail. 

Security Notes

The SAP Sales Cloud domain was added to the App Router allowlist (whitelist) to ensure that SAP Cloud is able to load the widget in an iframe. we need to configure the whitelistService propery in xs-app.json.

{
  "whitelistService": {
    "endpoint": "/whitelist/service"
  },
  "responseHeaders": [
    {
      "name": "Content-Security-Policy",
      "value": "frame-ancestors https://*.crm.cloud.sap"
    }
  ],
  "routes": [
    {
      "source": "^/whitelist/service$",
      "localDir": ".",
      "authenticationType": "none",
      "cacheControl": "no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate"
    }
}

For more information, please visit @sap/approuter in npmjs.com.

Configure SAP Sales Cloud CTI Configuration

There are a few CTI settings that need to be enable first to make the widget show up inside SAP Sales Cloud V2. 

  • Enable CTI Integration --> See SAP Help Portal
  • Register the Widget --> See SAP Help Portal 

Source Code 

The base code is available on Github as a public repo.

Repository Name: gizemsoylutr/sales-cloud-cti-widget

entry.title: Introducing User-Defined Reports (UDR) in SAP Responsible Production and Design
entry.content:
Disclaimer: This blog post reflects the state of SAP Responsible Design and Production (RDP) as of November 25, 2025.

SAP Responsible Design and Production (RDP) released User-Defined Reports (UDR) this year, extending its reporting framework with a fully configurable, customer-driven approach developed to support customers with the ever-evolving and growing number of Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) regulations. With UDR, users can now create customized EPR reports for packaging based on their unique business and compliance needs.

UDR also enables SAP and in the near future, content partners, to offer templates for new EPR schemes that customers can copy into their own systems, to help them expand EPR reporting quickly. This new functionality aims to ease the burden of managing reporting obligations across multiple markets.

This blog post explains the background and motivation for this feature, provides a sneak peek into the key functionalities used to create country-specific EPR report categories, and highlights how this enhancement improves flexibility and extensibility for EPR data reporting.

Background

As EPR regulations continue to expand globally, businesses face increasing complexity in how they manage compliance. Regulations vary not only from country to country but often overlap or undergo changes over time, making it challenging for customers to keep up while relying on predefined reporting structures.

SAP RDP has long supported customers in meeting EPR requirements through SAP-provided report categories that are preconfigured to match the packaging obligations in countries such as Spain, Italy, and the UK. While these reports have served as a reliable foundation, there is a growing need for a more flexible and more nuanced reporting approach.

Companies increasingly require a way to:

  • Adapt quickly to new or changing legislation
  • Reuse rules and fee structures across similar reporting schemes or Producer Responsibility Organizations (PROs)
  • Consolidate data from diverse sources
  • Customize reporting logic based on their specific business context

This is exactly why SAP introduced User-Defined Reports (UDR): to provide customers with an agile, scalable, and future-ready foundation for building report categories aligned with regulatory logic, business context, and compliance requirements.

Key Capabilities of UDR

User-Defined Reports bring together several powerful capabilities that allow customers to design report categories tailored to their specific regulatory and operational needs. 

1 Build the Structure of Your Report

Responsible Organizations

EPR schemes are managed by Producer Responsibility Organizations (PROs). Many countries operate with more than one PRO, each offering different fee structures or criteria. In Spain, for example, Ecoembes manages general packaging, while Ecovidrio is responsible for glass packaging. UDR allows users to:

  • Attach multiple PRO-specific fee tables to the same report category
  • Reuse the same report fractions and rules across PROs
  • Avoid creating separate report categories for each PRO (as long as their rules do not conflict)

This gives customers flexibility in markets where several PROs coexist.

Report Fractions

Report fractions are the foundational building blocks of a UDR report. They represent the categories into which packaging is classified according to national legislation or PRO requirements. Fractions can be created and named based on the exact fee structure of the country or PRO, ensuring a one-to-one alignment with how fees are calculated.

Report Fraction Groups

To support cleaner structuring and reporting layouts, fractions can be combined into report fraction groups. These groups help users organize related fractions (for example, grouping all paper-related fractions) and simplify both calculation and reporting outputs.

2 Control the Logic Behind Your Report

Filters for Included Packaging

Filters add a foundational layer of control by allowing users to exclude packaging that should not be part of a particular report or fee calculation. They can be applied at multiple levels within the report category setup and help ensure that only relevant data is included based on the requirements of each EPR scheme.

Together with calculation rules, filters help shape a reporting outcome that aligns with legislative and business requirements.

Calculation Rules

Report calculation rules form one of the most powerful elements of UDR.
They determine which packaging is included in a report and how quantities and fees are calculated, giving customers the flexibility to reflect the exact compliance logic required by each market. Because calculation rules can combine multiple conditions, attributes, and data sources, they enable users to shape reporting logic precisely around their business and regulatory needs, making this capability central to the flexibility that UDR offers.

Calculation rules come with an extensive rule library that offers a wide collection of rule examples, expressions and functions that can be leveraged to fit the users’ reporting requirements.

Logistic Processes

Logistic processes represent the specific movements of products or packaging that are relevant for a country’s EPR legislation, such as domestic sales, imports, exports, or other flows defined by the market. In UDR, users can select which logistic processes apply to their report category and combine them with filters or calculation rules. This allows the user to reflect only the movements that are obligated in that country, ensuring the report aligns with how packaging enters or leaves the market.

 

3 Capture Sustainability-Driven Criteria

Ecomodulation

Many EPR schemes increasingly use ecomodulation to reward sustainable packaging choices. UDR allows users to set ecomodulation criteria based on the relevant EPR scheme and incorporate them into calculation rules. This further enables fees to be calculated according to the required ecomodulation rules. To learn more about ecomodulation, visit the SAP RDP community page for a detailed blog on this topic, releasing soon.

Recyclability

UDR also integrates recyclability outcomes directly into reports. When setting up a report, recyclability guidelines can be selected and applied, to be used in calculation rules when needed. This allows recyclability insights to feed directly into the report structure, supporting countries where recyclability affects fees or criteria (such as the bonus/malus payments on EPR fees in France). Users can either upload date manually via Excel or integrate with a partner of their choice.

4 Test and Validate Your Setup

Test Configuration

With test configurations, users can simulate the reporting outcome for one to ten products. This enables quick validation of rule logic, filters, and fee calculations before generating the full report, ensuring accuracy and reducing iteration time.

5 Templates

Not all EPR schemes have the same level of complexity. To ease the effort in building highly detailed report categories using UDR, Templates have been introduced; preconfigured starter packs that provide the structure and logic needed to get started, which can be adapted to fit the user’s requirements.

Currently, SAP provides Templates for US-Colorado, US-Oregon, and Denmark, with more to follow. Keep an eye on the SAP RDP Roadmap for upcoming additions.

Customer Response & Early Results

Customers who tested UDR shared strong and practical feedback, including:

“Only 25% of time and effort is required for using UDR compared to manual efforts.” (from consumer products company)

“First we were skeptic, but now we like using UDR.” (from food processing company)

These early insights reflect the impact of a flexible, user-driven reporting approach. To see this in a real-world setting, please check out our recent webinar, Navigating EPR regulations in the United States: Act Now! where our customer shares their experience with UDR.

What’s Next

UDR was shaped with direct input from customers, and this collaboration will continue. As EPR regulations evolve, SAP will focus on enhancing UDR, improving the configuration experience, and supporting reporting needs across markets.

One of the planned enhancements is around AI-assisted features that could make it easier to create calculation rules logic and work more efficiently with UDR using natural language.

Where to Learn More and Act!

To further explore UDR, detailed documentation with practical examples and additional guidance on calculation rules  available. You can also access a guided, step-by-step walkthrough showing how to create a UDR here.  We will continue to publish updates there as UDR evolves.

For broader product information on SAP Responsible Design and Production, we recommend browsing the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release. 

To take the next step, you can request a demo or contact us for a consultation. For additional regulatory context and practical guidance, you may also want to download our white paper on managing EPR regulations and plastic taxes.
